title: Snap Stock Turns Down Ahead of Earnings Even After an Upgrade
text:
Text size

Snap shares are falling on Friday after Bank of America Merrill Lynch analyst Justin Post lifted his rating on the social-media company’s stock to Buy from Neutral, setting a price target of $18. Post writes that a recent selloff in the shares provides a buying opportunity ahead of third-quarter earnings.

At least partially offsetting the bullish call, MKM Partners analyst Rohit Kulkarni picked up coverage of the Snapchat parent Friday with a Neutral rating, a $16 price target, and a highly cautionary research note.

Snap shares (ticker: SNAP) have had an eventful year. The stock more than tripled from $5.51 at year-end 2018 to $18.36 at its peak in July, then reversed course below $14 amid worries about the third quarter. The company is due to report third-quarter results after the close next Tuesday.

Merrill’s Post writes that investors appear to be concerned about both overly optimistic expectations for daily average user growth in the quarter and potential fourth-quarter weakness in average users. Recent checks suggest a decline in September and October ad user reach.

But he argues that strong downloads outside the U.S., increasing engagement with Snap’s Discover video content, and normal fourth-quarter usage “will drive user growth in line” with his forecast for 4 million net user adds, which is consistent with the Street consensus. In the second quarter, Snap added 13 million users, crushing Street estimates and driving up the stock price.

Post says the Street is likely expecting a $10 million revenue beat in the quarter, above the high end of the guidance range of $410 million to $435 million. He says there’s also optimism that revenue strength and continued expense management could lead to positive earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (Ebitda) for the company in the quarter, “which may be a catalyst for the stock.”

Editor's Choice

Meanwhile, Post is upbeat on Discover, which he sees boosting monetization, and he says that the launch of dynamic ads “will give Snap a new format to better compete for e-commerce spend in 2020.” He also sees acceleration of the streaming-video market boosting online video ad spending over the next two years, and slightly raised his revenue forecast for next year as a result.

He concludes that the stock’s valuation decline to 8.8 times on an enterprise value to 2020 sales basis “presents a better entry point” for the stock.

MKM Partners’ Kulkarni has a more cautious stance. “We do not believe that Snap has a long-term sustainable competitive moat, given the history of user growth and engagement lumpiness,” he writes. “Near-term, we believe competitive headwinds from TikTok and Instagram are rising.... Snap is trading at a premium valuation multiple to its peers and expected growth, implying high investor expectations over the near term, thus, we expect near-term choppiness in Snap shares as company fundamentals catch up to the shares’ premium valuation.”

Snap shares are trading down 0.7%, at $13.69, in recent trading. The S&P 500 is down 0.2%.
